data.text: Left Pedal Crank Falling off the Bicycle

I love my KONA Sutra but for the 2nd time I have experienced the issue of a SHIMANO DEORE left pedal crank falling off completely. First time I was in shock as I have never had a bike with such system and I never expected a failure of this kind. First time was on a pretty much new bike after 300km. I then took the bike to my LBS for fixing thinking it might just have been not fitted properly to start with and after another 300 km I had it happen again. This being a bike I plan to use for long term touring in the future I feel a bit concerned about the issue. Not something I would enjoy happening if touring in a remote part of the world! The crankset both times fell completely off and besides being dangerous if it happens in traffic I suppose the crankset could get lost or damaged and you are in for a very long walk... Has anybody similar issues? Is it advisable to replace this system for something more old fashioned, reliable and sturdy??? Looking forward to some advice!
How does it come it falls of? I don't know this system but is it possible your bolts need to be tightened with a little bit of loctite? You have multiple versions of loctite.

data.text: these cranks (and associated other models) are awesome for touring. Can easily be removed trackside with a multi-tool. never creak. AND, when installed correctly, cannot simply fall off. If installed correctly there should be a plastic safety device in the slot retained by the bolts. It has a little ‚Äòtit‚Äô on it that is supposed to engage with a small hole in the axle. The purpose is to retain the crank arm should the bolts come loose. Check it is not upside down or not pushed down before pinch bolts are done up. Discalaimer. This safety device pisses me off so i remove and discard when i fit a new set of this style of shimano cranks because I have NEVER had a set come loose!!! Note, the plastic end cap is purely to pre-load bearings and has nothing to do with holding crank on. Do it up say finger right and the tighten the 2 pinch bolts with a 5mm hex key.

data.text: Sounds like a real bothersome problem. You really shouldn't be getting enough leverage to pull the crank off twice in so little mileage. So either the bolts aren't done up (twice)/or you are getting leverage on your crank arm that you shouldn't be. I've never done this on a hollowtech crank in a few hundred thousand km's of randonneuring, bikepacking and commuting, despite being overweight. Had lots of other different issues though!!! - What model year is your Sutra? - Do you know the exact spec of the bottom bracket installed? - Can you send back photo from the underside of your you bike with a caliper or ruler measuring the shell width? Alternatively, take the cranks out and see how the left crank fits off the bike vs on. I think the crank arm is either not going fully onto the crank axle or there is too much space for your pedal arm. If too much or too little width across the crank axle, start with the bottom bracket and spacer configuration. The arm coming off may be the symptom, not the cause. Too much space will give it leverage to work it's way off. Too little, will mean it isn't engaging at the spines and you would be pressing outward on the crank axle with every spin. In both cases it has not been installed correctly.

data.text: I looked up the technical documents on the Shimano website and there's a warning about the possibility of this happening with hollowtech left cranks. Here's the relevant section for my 105 crank set: - The two left crank arm mounting bolts should be tightened alternately and incrementally rather than each bolt being fully tightened all at once. Use a torque wrench to check that the final tightening torques are within the range of 12 - 14 N¬∑m. Furthermore, after riding approximately 100 km (60 miles), use a torque wrench to re-check the tightening torques. It is also important to periodically check the tightening torques. If the tightening torques are too low or if the mounting bolts are not tightened alternately in stages, the left crank arm may come off during the ride causing the rider to lose control and fall. * Service Instructions in further languages are available at: http://si.shimano.com Please note: specifications are subject to change for improvement without notice. ¬© Jan. 2016 by Shimano Inc.
